reviewText: Having seen (in the UK) all the original Cinerama Movies, this release is a very welcome addition to my Bluray collection.  The restoration must have been one hell of a task and credit is due to all concerned.  I did not expect any super clear picture or magnificent 7 channel sound but so delighted to see and hear the overall quality obtained from a 60+ uear old negative that has been lying around, mostly ignored for all these years.  Living in the UK and not too far from Bradford's Pictureville Cinema I often take the oppportunity to visit their annual Widescreen Festival and was also present at the opening of the giant Cinerama Screen there.  I have to say the quality on this Bluray Disc is much better than the one shown on opening night there (and does not break down)

reviewText: I must admit that the film has aged both in visual impact as well as style.  Even with the "SmileBox" treatment, it doesn't have the impact of HTWWW, probably because it was made from a single 70mm print. (thus losing some width and one sprocket hole in height.)  It's still fun to view some once memorable sections, the score holds up well, and the reproduction of the original program (except for size) is a nice addition.
summary: This Is Cinerama - with a little less "Cinerama!"
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Is Cinerama kicked off the cinema changes of the 1950s when television began taking over as the primary form of entertainment.  Movie studios and exhibitors began scrambling to find ways to bring people back to the theaters; they hadn't yet understood that their ticket buying audience shifted to the 15-30 years olds and it would be the late 1960s before the big studios would figure that out.  Still, the 1950s saw the standard movie frame change from Academy ratio 1:33 to 1 (original television mimicked this) to 1:85 to 1 (the current 16:9 ratio of HD television) and Cinemascope, VistaVision, Todd AO 70, Super Panavision, Ultra Panavision 65, Technirama, 3D and other wide screen aspect ratios try to make the movie experience bigger and better, and bring people back to cinemas.The granddaddy of all was Cinerama, a three element synchronized photography and projection system that captured a 150 degree field of vision.  It was spectacular in the cinema and was the star of the show, that's why I only give three stars.  The Smilebox presentation adequately mimics the experience but nothing at home can match the power of seeing it in theaters. And the film itself, well, it's not all that exciting to watch for two hours at home.  Thus, the three stars.  Still, it is a time capsule from the past and well worth seeing, if not necessarily buying it.
summary: A Time Capsule From the Past
Title: N/A

reviewText: I did a term paper on the process in early 1973...10 years after the last 3-strip Cinerama film was shown in Toledo. Another downtown theater that had a 70mm Cinerama projection system in mothballs brought it back to life...temporarily...in April of 1973. I did see a few 70m films shown on the Cinerama screen and it wasn't bad. Now that SmileBox is available it is my hope that many of the 70mm films presented in Cinerama or Todd-AO in addition to 3-strip Cinerama will be in the offing for viewers at home. As an added note for those of you that may have a 3D television...I found that by converting How The West Was Won to simulated 3D gives the SmileBox curved screen a whole different look. Watch it in a dark room and you will swear that you have a curved screen coming out of the wall of your viewing room.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the middle 1960s, I saw "This Is Cinerama" at least three times in a genuine Cinerama theater on the huge, deeply curved screen and using the original three projection process.  These two aspects and excellent sound reproduction are what provided the impact of original Cinerama.  Later films using a single projection system such as "2001: A Space Odyssey" that was printed in Super Panavision 70 were introduced on the Cinerama screen, which while impressive, did not have the impact of the original Cinerama system.  I also saw a few of the later Cinerama productions using the three projector process: "Cinerama Holiday," and "South Sea Adventure," etc. that were great.The Blu-ray release of "How the West was Won" which included the "Smile Version" intended to recreate the Cinerama experience  was simply silly.So while the idea of releasing "This Is Cinerama" on Blu-ray is a nice gesture, I don't get the point.  Seeing it on a flat screen TV at home will be, at best, a weak reminder of what original Cinerama looked like.  In the case of Cinerama, the medium was the message.
Title: N/A

reviewText: *sigh*, I was really looking forward to this but I'm pretty disappointed. First, my DVD (not blu-ray) won't play much of the material. It's like the disc was scratched or dirty (which of course it is not). But even the parts I was able to see were rather disappointing.The original film consists of 26 or so vignettes; a bullfight, an opera, etc. But the first segment is in cropped B&W;, like they were making fun of television. So that segment is sort of a waste. The sound is very poor, even by monophonic standards for most of what I could see.Even many of the color segments are unimpressive on a modern HDTV screen. The bullfight scene for example shows the whole bullring, but on a 48" TV it's all pretty small and you can't see much. Another black & white scene in a church with choir members marching in from behind the camera and forming up in front merely highlights the crazy optical distortion caused by the cinerama process (I guess). The people appearing on the left and right of the camera marching in appear 12' tall, and the people at the far end look like midgets.In all the segments I saw the breaks between the three cinerama camera angles seemed to be more visible on TV than I recall from the theater. This may be partly due to the fact that you can see the whole screen at once, whereas in the theater you had to turn your head.On a more positive note, the Roller Coaster and Cypress Garden segments were pretty good. I can't view the flight through the Grand Canyon on my disc but I'll bet that works too.But in general, this DVD just serves to highlight the many issues with Cinerama.There appear to be a lot of Bonus features, which may be very nice if I can view them. But the basic "Smile Vision" Cinerama experience simply doesn't come off well.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The new This Is Cinerama Blu-ray is an excellent blast from the past. The video is crips and clear. Audio is also excellent. Be sure to view the restoration video in the extras menu. It shows the painstaking process they used to restore the movie to its original beauty.I must say I'm very much impressed how they restored the film considering what they had. My only complaint is that, due to budget contstraints, they were not able to use the original three panel negatives to do this restoration. They used a 65mm composite (one strip of film) that was used in the 1973 revival (took one star off for that. Hey, I'm a purist :) ).With that said however, if you project this Blu-Ray up on a large screen (100" or bigger), it looks spectacular and gives you the general feeling of what it was like in the original Cinerama theaters. They color corrected everything, took out blemishes and balanced each panel to look exactly the same. You can still see the lines but after a while you won't notice them because they really aren't all that bad.Bravo to the folks who restored this film. It's just about as close as you can get to Cinerama in your home. If you have been wanting to see this film in all its glory, buy this Blu-Ray now. This is the best way to watch the film at home.By the way, for all of you Apple fans, the entire feature was restored and edited on a Mac with Final Cut Pro.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wow, this Blu-ray was a gift from my son.  The SMILEBOX sure works great for me.  5 stars for thatI remember back  around 1955 seeing this film at the Tennessee Theater in downtown Nashville, Tennessee.It was just amazing.  The  minor joint lines and optical distortion on some of the A and C frames are normal to me as they were on the original showing at the theater. I actually expected them. However, it was no big deal.  In most of the shots the joint lines did not even show up.Excellent editing and restoration. 5 stars for that too.  I think it is great that Amazon has sold out of the first offering of this disc.I believe that if you actually saw the film in a theater, you can understand and appreciate the Smilebox presentation. As with the Blu-ray, I could see the stage and above the top of the screen.  Smilebox is so realistic to represent the actual theater event.I would always try to sit in row 5 or 6 and as close to the center as possible.  It was overwhelming.  HOW THE WEST WAS WON was great in thetheater. I would love to see THE WONDERFUL WORLD OF THE BROTHERS GRIM  in the SMILEBOX format too. I have it on laserdisc, but it is rather poor picture quality when projected on my 92" screen.The 19 minute restoration part of this Blu-ray disc is so interesting to me.  I was amazed at the challenges in restoring the film on a limited budget. Makes me feel a bit better about the $39.95 price tag.  I hope all involved were paid fairly for their excellent efforts.  Again, 5 stars for the restoration.Now then, I would appreciate some comments on my next observation.  This is the reason I gave it a 3 star rating. If that caught your attention, maybe you can help me. I had just finished watching the new release(UK) of  Lawrence of Arabia, 50th anniversary Edition on Blu-ray and and then I watched THIS IS CINERAMA. Must have been a mistake on my part.  I normally sit 10 feet from my 92" screen, then, as suggested by an earlier reviewer, I put a chair about 6 feet from the screen to get the full CINERAMA impact as I remembered it back in the 1950s.  Was I ever dissappointed.  The picture was soft and almost looked a bit out of focus.  Some of the scenes were better, but overall, the picture resolution was at best like some older DVD releases.  The color was always great.  I am sorry to be critical on this , but maybe I AM expecting too much.  Perhaps I am doing something wrong.  Positive suggestions are welcome.EDIT-EDIT-EDIT.  One month later I have discovered an excellent solution.  I just happened to take the disc downstairs and watch it on our 37" LCD TV.  Made all the difference in the world.  Much sharper picture.  Much better.  Problem solved!!!Thanks

reviewText: Have waited for decades for this spectacle to arrive on home video. I'm glad they waited for Blu-ray. My parents took my sister and I to this landmark film in 1952 at the Century Cinerama Theatre in downtown Minneapolis, which had been converted from a regular movie theatre. I saw it a couple of more times at the Century during its 2-year run. I saw it again years later at the suburban Cooper Cinerama Theatre in St. Louis Park, which replaced the Century Theatre which was razed in the early 1960s. That showing, however, used only one central projector instead of the three. The three panels had been optically merged onto one strip of 70mm film (I assume) to eliminate the chance of bad sychronization. The picture lost some effect as there was noticable truncation of the left and right panels resulting in a narrower picture. The Blu-ray picture is excellent and the SmileBox version provides as close as possible to the original experience. Excellent job of the transfer including trying to erase the overlap lines between panels.

reviewText: Remarkably, for those of us who saw "real" Cinerama in the 60's, this is a nostalgic journey. I doubt those who have not experienced the real thing will enjoy this traveloge. The Smilebox format actually works well but only on a very large television.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was twelve or thirteen years old in the early 1950's when two of my doting Aunts took me on a weekend trip to Dallas, Texas where the old Melba Theatre had been modified to offer the first presentation of Cinerama in the Southwest United States. Some time later the Windsor Cinerama Theatre was opened in Houston. I had read about Fred Waller and Cinerama in an issue of Readers Digest. We did not even have television in any of our family homes at that time. The opening roller coaster sequence was almost too much. And the La Scala opera segment of Aida was breathtaking. But, nothing could prepare you for the air plane shots that probably caused many watchers to become a little woozy. I have waited for years for this to become available on DVD and now several of those early productions are offered on DVD. The film is a little dated, but, the spectacle has not lost its impression.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I especially liked This Is Cinerama when i first saw it 55 years ago on the big screen. While the smilebox process is not perfect, it really does give some idea of what Cinerama was like. I would hope to see the other travelogs in this process as well as the Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm. This DVD should be in schools as it gives a birds eye view of what America was like in the early 1950's. You see New York City before the World Trade Center, Chicago before the Prudentail Building, and other places we are all familiar with. Salt Lake City, the open pit mine, the Grand Canyon. I would have liked it better had they played the music of the Grand Canyon Suite here, but they did not. Lowell Thomas' narration is a little bit lacking, as not everything is explained, but it can be overlooked. It was absolutely amazing the way they spiced everything together in the Flight Across America sequence so it appeared to be seemless. I thought the Cypress Gardens sequence was overdone and some other parts drag a bit, especially the Aida. All in all, it is still fun to watch.

reviewerName: Lawrence C. Dupont "Retired 20 year U.S. Navy...
reviewText: My first introduction to Cinerama was in NYC in 1955, I was 11 years old. A family trip to the Big Apple. Sitting in the 3rd row from the screen, surrounded by wine colored curtains, waiting for the show to start. I noticed 3 projection booths on the orchestra floor. Not knowing what Cinerama was, I thought it might be a new type of three dimension process. The lights went down, a b&w; mono sound prologue starts. After about 10 minutes into the prologue, I started to get bored. Nothing different about this movie. Then the narrator said "Ladies and Gentlemen, enjoy your Cinerama Holiday". The horizontal masking started to rise, the wine colored curtains started to open wider and kept going and going. We were flying through the sky, surrounded in picture and sound. WOW, WE DON'T HAVE THIS BACK HOME"Since that Saturday night at the Stanley Warner Times Square theater, I have been a big time fan of Cinerama. Making sure I saw everything and any thing that was released in Cinerama. In 1996, my wife and I drove for 24 hours (1400 miles) to see a come back of Cinerama in Dayton, Ohio. I flew to Seattle for the "Reel Cinerama Festival". I have been to Pacific's Cinerama Theater (fondly refered to as the Cinerama Dome)to see Cinerama productions.When "How The West Was Won" was released in "SmileBox" on Blu-Ray, I was over joyed. Now "This Is Cinerama", the first Cinerama production which changed forever the way we look at movies will be in my Cinerama Collection. I am a big Cinerama memorabella collector. I have one entire wall in my home theater dedicated to Cinerama. I can hardly wait to see it on my 92" diaganal screen. The Blu-Ray 1080p picture will show the great depth of field high quality photography Cinerama was famous for."This Is Cinerama" has no stars, no plot, but was the highest grossing box office hit of 1952, and it was playing in only one theater. "This Is Cinerama" gives you a breif history of motion pictures, takes you across our beautiful country and around the world. All in the "you are there" magic of the Cinerama Process. Cinerama definately "Puts You In The Picture" Thanks to the "Smile Box" process, it will look like you are watching on a curved screen, which adds to the enjoyment of the film so much.I recommend "This Is Cinerama" to anyone who is a Cinerama fan, movie buff or just wants to own a piece of American Cinema history.Yes it is not the same as seeing Cinerama in a Cinerama movie theater, but it is a great experience for any Cinerama fan, and there are thousands of us. No, tens of thousands of Cinerama fans around the world today.You can have the full Cinerama experience this coming month, Sept 28 - Oct 04, 2012. The Pacific Cinerama Theater in Hollywood, Ca will be having a week long festival in celebration of the 60th anniversary of the first public showing of Cinerama on Sept. 30, 1952. Twelve Cinerama Productions will be shown. Plus a new Cinerama film just completed called "In The Picture" This marks the first time that actual Cinerama cameras have been used in over 50 years. Five productions will be shown in the original 3 strip film process, Three digital presentations from the original 3 strip films, two digital productions from the 65mm prints and one presented in 70mm Ultra Panavision. All presented on the full 129 degree curved Cinerama screen. I beleive the screen dimensions are 89' wide and 32' high. I might be a little off on the screen size.
summary: After such a long wait - CINERAMA Comes To Home Video

reviewText: I was born in the 1950's, but I never got to see a Cinerama movie.  But now I have a home theater HD system with 7.1 surround.  I just got the movie, "This Is Cinerama" in the smilebox version on BluRay.  I was so impressed with the video and DTS HD Master Audio soundtrack in 7.1 surround.  The Smilebox really gives the illusion of the wrap-around screen effect with real depth and perception. And the 7 channel sound puts the voices exactly where they are seen on the screen.  I have watched it twice in the same week I got it in the mail.I also got the Cinerama movies "Windjammer" and "How The West Was Won".  They are all equally impressive in the Smilebox format.  I was so impressed, I did an atricle in tribute to Cinerama on my own website at k3dav.comThis is a must see movie, and a deep wish on my part to bring this wonderful format back to life with new and old movies.  Call or write the movies studios in Hollywood and ask them to do movies in the Cinerama format.

reviewText: When MGM released its superb restoration of HOW THE WEST WAS WON on Blu-ray early last year, I began to wonder if THIS IS CINERAMA might someday get the same treatment. And here it is, the first-ever home video release of the feature that launched the widescreen revolution of the 1950s.Unfortunately, budget limitations did not allow the producers to scan the original 35mm triple-negative, as was done for HOW THE WEST WAS WON. Instead, this program is sourced from the 65mm composite negative created for the 20th-anniversary re-release in 1972, which was itself sourced from a mediocre print.The result? Thanks to 18 months of heroic digital restoration, THIS IS CINERAMA looks surprisingly good. It's not as super-sharp as HTWWW; the blending between the three panels is not as smooth, and a few scenes suffer from too much contrast. But it's a respectable representation of an experience that can only be suggested by home video anyway.Thanks to Flicker Alley for making THIS IS CINERAMA available to those of us who don't live near one of the three theaters in the world still capable of showing the original properly.
summary: Long-overdue souvenir of a cinema classic
Title: N/A

reviewText: I must admit I'm taken aback a little at the perfectionism expressed in some reviews of the Blu Ray of "This Is Cinerama," an historic film that has been made viable for home video only by the leaps and bounds of recent technology. David Strohmaier, a man who has passionately championed Cinerama for more than 15 years, cared enough about this film to request and receive an arts grant for a restoration budget that is microscopic compared to what major studios spend on their classic back catalog titles. He turned a highly imperfect composite negative over to Greg Kimble, an expert digital restoration artist, knowing this would take a long time and be done more for love than money. Kimble spent 18 months repairing the flawed negative on his own, without help from anyone, doing as much restoration as the very limited amount of money allowed.That we have "This Is Cinerama" on home video at all is due to the persistence and commitment of these two men, and I am grateful to have it. Do I think it is the greatest film ever made? No. I think it is one of the most important films ever made, however; as important in its own way as George Melies's "A Trip to the Moon" or any of Edison's early films. And until funds exist to restore the badly damaged Eastmancolor three-strip negative of "This Is Cinerama," I'll take this heroic achievement with pleasure.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is basically a travelogue showcasing how the extreme wide aspect ratio could immerse the viewer in the scene.  So we get lots of long tracking shots with the camera on a boat, car, or airplane.  Also stuff like operas and festivals where a static camera captures all the action on a wide stage.  In other words, the sort of content you are most likely to have seen in an Imax theater.  In this restoration, as others have noted the resolution is a bit limited.  But with a little imagination one can realize what this must have looked like to the cinema audience when it was new.  They had never seen anything like it, so I expect few contemporary viewers noticed technical flaws that I notice today.This spectacular medium never really took off for making movies due to its limitations.  It's hard to imagine either character-driven dramas or fast-paced action movies being made with this process.  The special three-film camera was quite bulky.  Editing must have  been a nightmare.  Between the cumbersome camera and the challenges of editing, fast cuts would have been impossible and retakes very expensive.  Close-ups would have made the seams between the individual strips of film too obvious (the closer things get to the camera, the greater the parallax error inherent in filming with three lenses).  So making films this way entailed both a huge budget and severe artistic constraints.
summary: Shows the capabilities -- and limitations -- of Cinerama

reviewText: I built a curved screen to show Cinerama & Todd-AO movies via digital projector.  The formatting of this Blu-Ray disc reduces the size of the image by simulating a curved screen, which ironically does not fill my curved screen.  No other format option provided.  For anyone who remembers Cinerama sound the sound on this disc will be a letdown, even on high end speakers.  Bravo for preserving this historic event in motion pictures, but it won't "put you in the picture" or recreate the awesome sonic experience of the original.  Based on its presentation at the L.A. Cinerama Festival, the tech work on restoration of South Seas Adventure is the best of any Cinerama feature: here's hoping it will be available in the correct aspect ratio as well as a SmileBox simulation.

reviewText: Wow.I remember seeing THIS IS CINERAMA, at the Hollywood Cinerama Theatre on opening week in 1954.I was in my last year of high school and saw it with my best buddy at a matinee. We were totally amazed, thought it better than 3D and couldnt wait to see the next one. Yes there were lines and color differences between the panels, but the whole was much better than the parts. All of that came flooding back as I watched the incredible blu-ray smilebox version. Best on a bigscreen, but watch it anyway you can, to see the film that completely changed the way we see theatrical and now television movies. And its very entertaining, though far more mundane than I remember. Now I am anxious to see some of the others like CINERAMA ADVENTURE, SOUTH SEAS ADVENTURE, WINDJAMMER,etc. which I also saw at that time. Hope this is successful enough to warrant a release of the others. If not, at least it will be a fine companion piece to the best of the Cinerama features, HOW THE WEST WAS WON, which also has a smilebox  blu-ray version. Worth every cent we paid.

reviewText: Viewers expecting an experience similar to the Warner Brothers release of "How the West Was Won" will be very disappointed by this attempt to recreate "This Is Cinerama".While I have no problem with the "smilebox" format, there is more involved in matching the three strips than was attempted here, and the optical distortion within each strip was not properly corrected, as was done on the HTWWW disc.It is commendable that an attempt was made, and it is good to have at least this version. But it is also easy to imagine a version with better optical correction.This version is good, but it could have - and should have - been better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This release, done with obvious affection and great care, will give those who don't know or remember SOME idea of what Cinerama was like, and of course those who do remember will feel a sentimental thrill when once again Lowell Thomas trumpets, at the conclusion of the too-lengthy prologue, "THIS is Cinerama!"  And then off you go on a literal roller-coaster ride that, at the time, had audiences all but screaming in their seats. From there the film embarks on a round-the-world and cross-country travelogue unlike any that had been seen before. But it has to be noted: of all the hundreds of movies release on video, probably none suffers more from diminution than this one. That is, a gigantic, IMAX-sized curved screen was an absolutely essential part of the unique and dazzling sensory experience, and of the aesthetic experience as well.  Reduced to TV size, even a 60-inch high-deffer, the film underwhelms, and you'll likely grow restless by the stately pace and the static camera work (the 3 interlocked cameras were far too cumbersome to move around very much).  I hate citing the shortcomings, however, because I did enjoy seeing even a replica of Cinerama once again.  It remains a milestone, a uniquely golden moment in cinema, a treasure-on-film that richly deserves being revisited. And -- oh yeah, almost forgot -- much of what you'll see is heartwarmingly naive, salutary and beautiful.  Very very beautiful.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well where do I begin. I have waited a long time to see this film. My first exposure to Cinerama was the Blu-ray release of "How The West Was Won". I was not expecting the full restoration of that release. But there are some surprises.I think the restoration team has done a good job but there seem to be two big problems. Firstly, the details. Where are they? This print was supposed to be made from a 65mm copy. But, honestly, after first viewing it I had to look inside the box to make sure I had not inserted the DVD instead of the Blu-ray. One only has to look at the Cypress Gardens segment with all the vegetation to realize there is something missing here.Another issue is that many of the darker areas are so dark that any detail in this print is completely lost. For me this is most notable in the La Scala segment. Maybe there was too much fiddling with contrast or gamma here?The sound is moderately stereophonic and the orchestra is natural sounding. Very nice.The 3 Cinerama panels are aligned pretty well. Only a few times did I notice minor double images at the joints. The overall color is good but don't expect a fully restored Technicolor print. In Cypress Gardens the color seems more muted than in La Scala.Now to the film. I don't really care too much for the film itself. Sure, it is important from a historical perspective, but it was made to demonstrate the Cinerama process. And for me the segments are not that interesting and last way too long.The extras are very good.Now, if only this film had recorded Callas at La Scala doing Aida in '52, that would have been a miracle.Recommended.

reviewText: Was talking with wife about my 1st movie in a theater, was very impressed, picture, sound, was glad to see I can buy it, share it with my wife now, just need a Blue Ray player. The basket ride was great down the cobblestones, the sea, sail.  A must see. Loved when it went one screen to 3 times wider. Buy it!

reviewText: The BluRay release of "This Is Cinerama"  is presented in the amazing SmileBox format, just like "How The West Was Won."  The legions of Cinerama fans have been waiting for this release for what seems like a lifetime, so I rejoice that that time is near.  When I was in high school, I had the privilege of working in a Cinerama theatre in Wichita, Kansas and I remember all of these wonderful films.  The Cinerama process wasn't perfect visually, since one could see the lines where the three pictures joined on that huge curved screen, but once you became involved in what was going on, the lines seemed to disappear.  And what spectacular sound!  A full seven channels of directional stereophonic sound, coming at you from every direction and being reproduced on a separate audio magnetic playback machine.  This was indeed thrilling cinema and was many years ahead of it time both artistically and technically.There is a You-Tube preview of this release which was put together by David Strohmier and a host of other Cinerama "geeks" so if you haven't seen this yet, check it out.  You will be amazed!
